Kicking Horse, British Columbia, Canada. Image © PlanetSKI Kicking Horse is probably my favourite Canadian resort. Firstly it has some of the finest and most challenging skiing – from the steep shutes and wide open powder bowls, to the groomers. articles.title: POV Footage Shows Just How Wild Freeride Skiing Really Is
articles.description: It's pretty hard to understand just how intense freeride skiing runs really are without seeing it from the athlete's perspective.
articles.content: The first ever FIS Freeride World Championships went down on Tuesday, February 3rd, at Ordino Arcalís in Andorra, bringing 65 of the world’s best freeride skiers and snowboarders from 17 nations together for an epic competition. The winning runs were seriously impressive, but it’s pretty hard to understand just how insane these runs really are without seeing it from the athlete’s perspective. Ben Richards won the men’s ski category with a wild run, but his newly released GoPro footage really gives you a new appreciation for the steepness and intensity of the face at Ordino Arcalís. Ben’s first place finish beat French skier Ugo Troubat, who wound up in second, and American skier Kai Jones, who wound up in third. Make sure you catch every winning run here . Watch Every Winning Run From The First Ever Freeride World Championships Categories: Europe Freeride World Tour Skiing

articles.title: Two New 6-Seater Chairlifts Open In Dachstein-West
articles.content: With the grand opening of the two new 6-seater chairlifts, Aussichtsberg and Angeralm, the Dachstein West ski region has reached another significant milestone in its tourism development. The two new lifts connect the ski resorts in Gosau (Upper Austria) and Annaberg (Salzburg) and thus serve as a powerful symbol of cross-border cooperation in alpine tourism. Since their commissioning last December, they have noticeably improved traffic flow in the ski area and provided a new, modern skiing experience. “With the new Aussichtsberg and Angeralm 6-seater chairlifts, Dachstein West has achieved a true vision for the future. These lifts are a visible sign that targeted investments in quality, safety, and guest comfort are having an immediate impact. The high level of guest satisfaction confirms that we are on the right track. Around €22 million was invested in the two new lifts. articles.title: Vonn Claims Olympics is Still on the Cards
articles.description: Lindsey Vonn tore her ACL in a high speed downhill crash at a World Cup event in Crans-Montana last week. She has not ruled out taking part in next weekend's Olympic Downhill in Italy. NEW The post Vonn Claims Olympics is Still on the Cards appeared first on PlanetSKI .
articles.content: She says she is “very hopeful” she can compete at the Milan-Cortina Winter Olympics. Ski racers have competed with torn ACL’s before and Vonn crucially doesn’t have swelling on the knee. The former Olympic champion said her knee feels “stable, strong and is not swollen” and she feels “confident” she will make the women’s downhill event in Cortina next Sunday. “This is obviously not what I hoped for. I have been working really hard to come into these Games in a much different position,” she said. “I know what my chances were before the crash and I know that my chances aren’t the same as it stands now, but I know there is still a chance. “As long as there is a chance, I’ll try. That’s where I am.” The four-time world champion retired from the sport in 2019 but made a stunning comeback in December 2024 following a partial replacement of her right knee. Lindsey Vonn set to race again She is currently top of the World Cup downhill standings, with two race wins and three more podium finishes

articles.description: View this post on Instagram A new line has been written into Canadian ski mountaineering history. On January 18, 2026, pro skier Christina Lustenberger—widely known as “Lusti”— along with partners Brette Harrington and Gee Pierrel completed the first-ever descent of the North Glacier on Mount Deltaform in British Columbia. The expedition unfolded deep in the Canadian Rockies and demanded a […] The post Christina Lustenberger and Team Complete First-Ever Ski Descent of Mount Deltaform’s North Gla
articles.content: View this post on Instagram A new line has been written into Canadian ski mountaineering history . On January 18, 2026, pro skier Christina Lustenberger —widely known as “Lusti”— along with partners Brette Harrington and Gee Pierrel completed the first-ever descent of the North Glacier on Mount Deltaform in British Columbia. The expedition unfolded deep in the Canadian Rockies and demanded a full-spectrum commitment that blended endurance, technical climbing, and exposed skiing. According to details shared by Black Crows, Lusti’s sponsor, the team departed the Moraine Lake trailhead early on January 17, hauling gear in toboggans for 17 kilometers in temperatures as low as –18°C (0°F). High winds sent spindrift cascading off the surrounding walls as they moved toward their objective, eventually establishing camp deep in the Valley of the Ten Peaks . Conditions shifted overnight. By morning, calm air allowed the team to begin their ascent of Mount Deltaform via a series of exposed ramps

articles.title: Ski Guides Sued For $14.5 Million Over Fatal Avalanche
articles.description: The family of a skier who died from a backcountry avalanche is suing the guides and the cat-skiing company.
articles.content: Douglas County, Oregon — Another week, another Oregon ski industry lawsuit. Central Oregon Daily reports that the family of a deceased skier has sued a mountain guide company for $14.525 million over the actions that led to his death. The lawsuit is against the Diamond Lake Improvement Company (which owns the cat-skiing operations), the three guides, and Sierra Wilderness Seminars Inc. (the company from which the guides were hired). During the 2023-24 season, Brian Thomas Roberts was on a cat-skiing trip. Around that fateful day, the weather at Mt. Bailey featured freezing rain, heavy snow, and wind. Despite the avalanche report saying the risk was high, the trip leaders continued skiing that day because the report didn’t apply to Mt. Bailey. These guides were reportedly inexperienced with Mt. Bailey, which at least one more experienced guide brought up as a concern. Brian was the fifth to ski down on the final run of the day, with each individual being sent down in one-minute interval

articles.content: In March and April, the days grow longer and weather conditions become particularly favourable for skiing. It is the ideal time to enjoy the mountains and the slopes of Alta Badia, in the heart of the Dolomites, a UNESCO World Heritage site, where excellent snow quality and meticulously groomed slopes ensure a high-level experience even at the end of the season. From the Mont Blanc massif to the Queyras and across into the Swiss Valais, numerous skier-triggered and spontaneous avalanches point to a snowpack that remains structurally unstable, despite periods of fair weather and already-tracked slopes. Rather … Continue reading "Avalanche Activity in France & Switzerland: What the Snowpack Is Telling Us" The post Avalanche Acti
articles.content: Late January – 1 February 2026 Over the past week, avalanche activity across the Alps has followed a clear and worrying pattern. From the Mont Blanc massif to the Queyras and across into the Swiss Valais, numerous skier-triggered and spontaneous avalanches point to a snowpack that remains structurally unstable , despite periods of fair weather and already-tracked slopes. Rather than isolated incidents, the reports collected since late January describe reactive slabs, remote triggers, and persistent weak layers affecting a wide range of aspects and elevations. Much of the recent instability is consistent with wind-loaded slabs and foehn-driven snow transport , which can rapidly overload weak layers and create large, reactive avalanche conditions. Further reading: Why Wind is one of the Most Dangerous Avalanches Triggers. Foehn Winds and Rising Avalanches in the Alps. articles.description: While a cold spell and major winter storms are disrupting the normal day-to-day for millions of Americans, the folks down in Alabama are celebrating. That’s because Cloudmont Ski Resort, affectionately known as “Ski Bama,” on Lookout Mountain in Mentone, Alabama, has finally opened its doors this winter season. Though this marks Cloudmont’s 54th season, it has not always been smooth […] The post Cloudmont Ski Resort in Alabama Opens for its 54th Season appeared first on SnowBrains .
articles.content: Bluebird Day at Alabama’s lone ski resort. Photo: Cloudmont Ski Resort Facebook While a cold spell and major winter storms are disrupting the normal day-to-day for millions of Americans, the folks down in Alabama are celebrating. That’s because Cloudmont Ski Resort, affectionately known as “Ski Bama,” on Lookout Mountain in Mentone, Alabama, has finally opened its doors this winter season. Though this marks Cloudmont’s 54th season, it has not always been smooth sailing for Alabama’s only ski resort. This year is a major comeback for the resort. It is the first time in the last five years that Cloudmont has opened for a full season . The resort owes this to the tremendous winter storm that plunged more than half the country into freezing temperatures, allowing it to make snow. Cloudmont relies on man-made snow as it only averages two to six inches of snowfall per year. articles.title: Professional Skier Puts Exoskeleton To The Test In Ski Mountaineering Race
articles.description: Alex Hackel raced world record holding ski mountaineer Noah Dines with an exoskeleton to see if it would be enough to give him the win.
articles.content: Noah Dines is pretty much as close to superhuman as one can get in ski mountaineering. He holds the world record for the most human-powered vertical feet skied in a year, totaling 3,590,097 feet. For 348 days, Noah skied an average of more than 10,000 feet a day. Alex Hackel is a top-notch skier in his own right, earning both a bronze and silver medal at the X Games in Real Ski. He is not a ski mountaineer, but he decided to race Noah Dines in a skimo race anyways. He gave himself a little boost for the contest, though, wearing the Hypershell X Series exoskeleton to see if it could give him enough of a boost to beat a world record holder. Despite throwing several challenges in Noah’s way, Alex having a mechanical boost, and Alex fully skipping a lap to make it a closer race, Noah was able to secure the win. articles.content: Winter mountains offer some of the most rewarding experiences in the Alps — from skiing and ski touring to snowshoeing and cross-country skiing. They are also complex, constantly changing environments , where risks are not always obvious and are not limited to one activity. This guide provides a clear, practical overview of winter mountain safety , helping skiers, snowshoers and Nordic users better understand terrain, conditions and context . It is written for awareness — not blame — and is designed to be read alongside official safety advice and avalanche bulletins. 1. Winter mountain risk goes beyond marked pistes A common misconception is that avalanche danger only concerns off-piste or backcountry skiers.
